## 1.  Representation theory of a finite group – the big picture  

Let \(G\) be a finite group (order \(|G|=n\)).  
A **representation** \(\rho : G\rightarrow GL(V)\) is a homomorphism into an invertible linear map on a complex vector space \(V\).  
Two representations are *equivalent* if there is an invertible linear change of basis that intertwines them.

### 1.1  Irreducible representations (irreps)  

- An irrep cannot be written as a non‑trivial direct sum of subrepresentations.  
- Over \(\mathbb C\) every representation decomposes uniquely (up to order) into a direct sum of irreps:
  \[
  V \;\cong\; \bigoplus_{\alpha} m_\alpha \, \rho_\alpha ,
  \]
  where each \(\rho_\alpha\) appears with multiplicity \(m_\alpha\).

### 1.2  Key theorems  

| Theorem | Statement (short) | Why it matters |
|---------|-------------------|----------------|
| **Maschke’s theorem** | Every complex representation of a finite group is completely reducible (i.e. decomposes into irreps). Moreover the averaging inner product \(\langle v,w\rangle_G=\frac1{|G|}\sum_{g\in G} \langle\rho(g)v,\rho(g)w\rangle\) makes any subrepresentation orthogonal, guaranteeing a complementary invariant subspace. | Guarantees that we can always split representations and work with orthonormal
